In the fall of 2020, almost five years ago at this point, I made the following prediction. Look, a few more years out, I'd been Palantir for the beginning of 2025 at a bare case of $100, target of $200, and a bull case of $300. Now, keep in mind that's five years from now. Please understand that these are arbitrary targets. I didn't run any sort of models to get here. It's just how I'm feeling about the company so far. Now, what do you... That's crazy.

This was on one of my most popular early videos on Palantir. I hope all of you made a lot of money off of this prediction, and it's even surprised me in terms of the accuracy of it. I've been waiting to make this follow-up because I try and have integrity around these things. Palantir stock passed 100, crashed below it. Now, we've regained that. So, I feel it's fair to make the victory lap video and also tell you what's happening from here. So, it's good to be back with you all. I've had some time off from making videos on Palantir and thought a lot about the future of this company as well as, you know, reflecting on everything that's gone right and the journey so far. Could not be more excited to present to you today my 2026 target for the stock, which is from the next 12 to 18 months in the upside scenario. But before we get into that, I first want to address what's happened from 2020 to 2025. Very important history and context and my insights because if we don't address this, it's not going to make sense what I say in the second half of the video.

So in 2020, Palantir IPOed, shout out to all of my day ones. IPO, obviously direct listing, interchangeable terminology with several fundamental red flags that kept many investors on the sidelines. So, as of our last fiscal year and as we are through Q1, Q2, heading into Q3 and finishing up the year in Q4, most of those worries have been measurably resolved through the consistent gap profitability first and foremost. I mean, that's just huge. We're going to be going through these one by one, but profitability is tremendous, strong free cash flow, and a much broader customer base. So, let's take a look at the matrix that I've assembled here. So, in 2020, here's what it looked like. Chronic gap losses of a billion dollars and runaway stock-based compensation. An overreliance on government, meaning more than half of the revenue came from government. And the other remaining amount, Foundry, that 40% or so, was viewed as bespoke consulting, almost very thin backlog and visibility. It was very unclear what the growth was going to look like and a fairly weak balance sheet. I wouldn't say it's the weakest balance sheet ever, but in comparison, and it's very important to say these were real and valid concerns. We overcame them as investors. We did a lot of research and what actually we were supposed to be concerned about. And it turned out none of these were deal breakers in 2020. But it's also important to say that these were real concerns. They were not, you know, FUD or made up or in any way fabricated. These were real problems that kept institutions out of the stock. But here's how it looks now. Obviously, profitability has exploded. We have these stable cash flows. SBC is now deteriorating as a percentage of revenues. Government overreliance is no longer a concern. Commercial is growing like crazy. And you know, you can no longer make the argument that it is a consulting company. Foundry has been modularized. Tough word to say. And the boot camps have really put a dent in that concern. And the, you know, cash situation and paying off the debt is also making a tremendous difference. So why does it matter? I'm not going to spend a lot of time here, but it showed that Palantir has gone through and really dismantled and debunked all of the fundamental concerns when it came to the fundamentals of the company. So, it really has been a true turnaround story. If I go back to the stock here, the Bears really did win when they drove the stock from $45 down to below $6. Like, objectively, the Bears won over that period of time. That was the first half of the company's public life. There's obviously been a second story. There's been another story to the second half of the public company's life, but you got to give it to them. They were right from that period of time. You were you were definitely out over your skis. If you're buying Palantir at $45 when you could have later bought it at a more objectively a depressed valuation, like you you got it for a steal if you were buying below six. But nevertheless, the bears were right at that period of time. We're going to be talking about this, but it was unfair to value Palantir as a software company or AI company at that point in time. Now, obviously, things have changed productization and the AIP flywheel. So, we launched AIP in April of 2023, created that turnkey skew, right? And the 5-day pilot program and is you know just I would just say days, hours, and days converts a tremendous amount of trials into paid contracts, something we've been hearing more about, and the average AIP deal size is up huge. We have the commercial land and expand, which has been an ever-increasing part of the story, commercial revenue growing 70%, the top 10 commercial clients have tripled, and operating discipline has been tremendous. The headcount flat while revenue has grown. SBC capped in the low 20s of sales and the cash operating expenses per employee are down. So across the board, incredible operating discipline and capital allocation. Zero debt. This should say on the order of 50 million in buybacks offsetting some of that stock-based compensation dilution. And you know, they're in the position to if they want to do any select tuck-in M&A and strengthen that vertical IP, although we know and what's been a obviously thesis point from the beginning has been you know internal growth in terms of product. So remains to be seen what they're going to do there. But coming to the remaining open questions, you know, these are just things that seem obviously a lot less important than they did in 2020.
